pros: Good co-workers best students and amazing faculty
cons: no cons actually great place to work and grow as an individual.

review_title: Good people but toxic environment by leadership teams
pros: People are friendly. Pre covid, the campus was lovely and a reminder that you're working at a University. There are a lot of people working here who have been here their whole working lives and you can see why they are happy to stay.
cons: Leadership team have no clue what they are doing and don't really listen to the problems or simply ignore them. As an IT department, the reputation is so bad that schools/departments avoid using them at all costs. Lots of shadow IT done where they prefer to get their own IT or get 3rd parties to do what the internal IT team should be doing. Technology used is so outdated and I've never been in an environment where things break so often. Certain teams avoid work and there is no respect for management/leadership teams. If you're looking for IT role, avoid this at all costs. Main reason I left was so I could learn an progress my IT career, something that is impossible to do here.

job_title: Laboratory Technical Manager in Mile End, England
pros: A relaxed, flexible working environment with a high pension and an open discussion with seniors when there is a problem. They are all fantastically brilliant people who are famed in their own right, but that can be to their own detriment too. Talking to the PhD students is fun and engaging and the content of the work is very interesting when getting into the mix of things.
cons: An unfortunate reality of academia and something I wished I knew before starting. The job is unbelievably lonely, ignoring the directors all doing their own thing, the staff age gap was averaging around 40+ years to a recent masters grad. The expectation is to work in isolation for essentially weeks at a time if you do not go out and find colleagues who are doing the same thing. The staff events numbered in around 3 for the whole year I was with them, to which all the staff promptly went home after 9. If you don't fit in the clique (very easy to do that), it becomes even more isolating. Essentially - if you are finding yourself, trying to meet people or just generally an extrovert, do not bother working there. You'll find yourself to be depressed very quickly. I admit the staff were all nice to a degree, but they do not care about you outside of what they have to do, and will readily leave you in your box office for an eternity, or until you just stop working and then they complain about you.

review_title: being a lab demonstrator at QMUL

review_title: No support for junior faculty or early career researchers
pros: You are in London. Teaching quality is high. Junior faculty are often very strong.
cons: Extreme and unreasonable admin burden. You will spend most of your time doing trivial amdin tasks rather than actual teaching or research. No transparency or fairness in the grant funding or PhD studentship allocation. The procedure has been a fiasco. Senior faculty, in key positions of power, allocate multiple studentships to themselves. This results in them having 5-7 PhD students, while early career researchers (ECRs) or junior faculty find themselves with 0-1 students, with no support when they need it the most, at the very start of their careers. This limits the ECR's career advancement prospects and hurts their grant applications, which results in a snowball effect, that amounts to career suicide. Many ECRs departed the Schools of Mathematics and Physics after last year's fiasco, highlighting the lack of support by the School. Do you think that changed anything? No. Leadership cannot take a hint, and repeated the same fiasco this year. In the latest staff survey, the leadership approval rating was 25%.

review_title: Staff mean well but there are a lot of issues
pros:
Nice students and staff
Standard academic package of benefits
Flexible working available
cons:
Building works always mean space shortages
Poor planning means low staff retention general and lots of movement as people are frustrated
High staff turnover leaves lack of consistency
Does not continue term of service from other academic posts
Long standard probation period and lots of hurdles without adequate infrastructure or support in many instances
No standard on sabbatical or overseas posts meaning some teams don't get any research leave while others get long periods
Use of teaching contracts that give no research support and funding to some staff, including no funds to even attend conferences (check your contract as some have been surprised that they have been put on a track and not told)
Over-reliance on fixed term contracts at lecturer level

review_title: Under valued, overworked, underpaid & restructures of teams every 2 years.
pros: I love my colleagues a lot.
cons:
Restructures occur every couple of years. People are left with insurmountable amounts of work and jobs which are paid at lesser grades than before. 

Pay for the past 5 years has gone up in tiny amounts (0.9%, 1%, 1.1%, 1.2%, 1.8%...) and its made clear that they don’t believe staff are worth it. 

Put it this way, a lecturer at the university (in London, with London weighting) is on a starting salary of £37k, rising to £44k. A tube driver can earn £52k, a commercial plumber can earn £50-60k, a plasterer can earn £50k.

review_title: This is too short a review
pros: Location is perfect as i can travel from outside of London and not have to pay for zone1 travel. the people are great, a diverse workforce, very helpful and  friendly. The onsite gym. The benefits are great and the support from the company brilliant if you have problems outside of work.
cons: the training is not great, but they do have loads of soft skill courses. flexibility to work on projects by management.

job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in London, England
pros: World leading research! Lots of opportunities for collaboration. very flexible working hours

job_title: Change, Release and Deployment Manager in Harlow, England
pros:
Conveniently situated in East London with easy access by tube lines and in zone 2.
Nice and quiet once away from Mile End Road.
It is moving up the UK University ratings which is good to feel part of.
cons:
Low salary compared to private sector.
No/Limited career progression
Distrust between business and IT Department
Distrust between internal IT Teams

pros: Very good work life balance. Pension is fantastic. Salary is below average for London, however holidays are above average.
cons: It is not a challenging or motivating place to work. It's a stagnant environment with no progression whatsoever. You are micro managed to death and not trusted to come up with any solution. Impossible to inject change to the environment.

pros: Culturally, ethnically diverse population of staff and students. Bright and inspiring colleagues who are mostly world class in profile, reputation and expertise.
cons: The QMUL aspirations are set high, so expect to work hard to fit in. This can make those who are struggling for funding or to get established to feel under a lot of pressure.

pros: I have learnt many technical skills such as Matlab, R, Python in one year. Additionally, there are many projects that can help students to boost their confidence and improve their soft skills. Some lecturers are best; they are patient and diligent. I would say I truly learnt a lot of knowledge and skills in one year.
cons: The table is too short. Hopefully, the students will have suitable tables in the future.

review_title: A great experience and a way to develop your people skills
pros: Tom was a great boss. The hours were very flexible and the pay for a student was very good. Lots of variety in the tasks you were asked to do; and lots of them were fun - showing kids how to program robots etc!
cons: Not always enough hours available (sometimes only 4 or so a week)

pros: Good collaborations amongst different groups, excellent pay, and benefits, strong mentorship programs, world-renowned research institutes, and great core facilities.There are excellent opportunities for teaching.
cons: HR and administration really let down the university research staff. There are too many delays in approved projects. No unified purchasing stores and an unreliable purchasing system.  IT/ equipment booking services could be better.There is also little transparency in selection and appointments for senior positions.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Assistant in London, England
pros: In the field of chemistry - nanotechnology there were both very stimulating environment and friendly people to collaborate with. There were a  number of career development courses and opportunities.Very international university campus with state-of-art facilities. New graduate building just opened few months ago.
cons: IT service took time to solve some problems a couple of times, but eventually worked it out. Lab spaces in chemistry department offer no view outside the building, so sometimes breaks are needed.

pros: Nice people, nice colleagues and a great environment. The IBMS is a great place to work, the lab facillities are good
cons: They can be overly up tight when working there. Most people are only in the lab between 10 and 4 after that its pretty empty, even during the busy hours its still empty

review_title: I have worked as Student Ambassador for a year
pros:
Pros: 
- huge amount of communication with prospective and current students
- possibility to get to bow your school better
- free lunch breaks during long shifts 
- fair pay, and very flexible working hours
- if you are an international student in the UK, it is great opportunity to see many cities, while working!
cons:
- Sometimes whether conditions were far from great during shifts 
- Heavy materials lifting

review_title: Tolerant and friendly but slow moving
pros: Diverse, professional and friendly. People on the 'ground' tend to be forward thinking and want to get things done for a better student and work life experience.
cons: Initiatives tend to move slowly and aspects of databasing, HR and IT Services are lacking and have yet to meet their potential.

pros: Good experience across the team - a lot of on-the-job training
cons: the organisation seems to be suffering from diseconomies of scale. Whilst some restructuring has taken place, much more needs to be done in general admin teams, and more staff for HR

pros: Good reputation and some prestigous scholarships available.
cons: Ignore student's concerns about their supervisors and students are blamed for any problems should they find the courage to complain which is highly frowned upon. Students are seen as trouble makers and snowflakes if any concerns are raised.

pros: Lots of support in terms of tech and with admin side of things. They do a very good job of dealing with everything else so you can focus on your work. I was provided with all the facilities I needed to work, to apply for funding, to travel to conferences.
cons: You can often be given extra responsibilities that are lumped on top of your normal job.

review_title: A collaborative working environment, great teams, great managers.
job_title: Human Resources Consultant in London, England
pros: Collaborative and collegiate working environment. Staff receive good development opportunities. Regular feedback, and benefits to include pension are good for the sector.  Great place to work.
cons: I enjoyed working at the College myself. However business support staff do tend to experience lesser quality office space due to budgetary reasons.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: It all depends on who's your supervisor. Mine was great, so was a great time overall.
cons: Poor social life, most members of the labs were inactive. I was in a lab with no collaborations whatsoever with the different ppl, as they were all working on different areas. Salaries are too low to compete with the industry, everybody in my lab was leaving, especially the young.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: QMUL is a top research university and some of the research groups are conducting leading work. Generally well equipped with core services for common research techniques.
cons: Highly competitive and stressed environment with very little opportunities for career progressions. Must be a self starter and write tons of papers, grants and fellowship applications to stand a chance of progressing.

job_title: Junior Software Developer in Mile End, England
pros: Good pay, flexible hours, contracted 35hrs/week + 2.5 days holiday per month
cons: Manager expected me to work extra hours every day without overtime pay. I worked on average 2 hours extra every day just to satisfy my manager.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Assistant in London, England
pros:
Working environment is generally good -- casual presentation and flexible time.
Coworkers are friendly and fun.
The salary is decent for academia.
cons:
Bad location in london.
Some bureaucratic admin paperwork to deal with (but maybe in common to all university rolls?)
Sometimes big pressure to deliver results

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mile End, England
pros:
- Strong organisational culture, a workplace that is true to it's values

cons:

review_title: Friendly People, great atmosphere, not very Exciting

cons: Not much of an exciting projects.

review_title: The worse job I have ever had to endure, strange belief systems that I believe are negative towards women. Bullying etc.
pros: The wages. Students great. Cash machine.
cons: Looks great from the outside.  Inside is bullying, sexism. Scared to ask questions as they make you out to be stupid. Gossip about you. You go there feeling great. Come out needing therapy. Be careful who you complain to. They are all related here.

review_title: Good studying atmosphere. Nice surroundings. Good students. People from different countries.
pros: Good studying atmosphere. Nice surroundings. Good students. People from different countries. School very good location. Close to sainsbury's. Great transportation. Close to tube and buses
cons: Slow staff. Teachers not caring. Very old school. Small canteen. Park is dirty. Library not that much journals and reference.

review_title: Decent job, good pay for what we’re expected to do
